newsitem.title: CHINA: China sets standards for 1997 firm interim reports.
newsitem.headline: China sets standards for 1997 firm interim reports.

text.p: China's top securities watchdog has set new requirements for 1997 interim reports by listed firms and ordered a fresh audit for firms which have posted losses in the past two years, the Shanghai Securities News said on Saturday.

The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) in a circular also ordered an audit for companies that want to issue rights and bonus shares and cash dividends in the second half of this year, the newspaper said.
Interim results in China have previously not required auditing.
The CSRC also told listed companies to explain in their interim results how they had invested money raised in share issues.
Companies which failed to invest the money in accordance with their issue prospectuses must explain why.

Firms which posted 1996 net profits more than 20 percent lower than their forecasts must give a full explanation and those which posted a 1996 loss must state what they have done in the first half of 1997 to regain profitability, the CSRC said.
The CSRC also urged exchanges to strengthen supervision of the interim reports to ensure the listed firms post accurate and comprehensive results.
